title: Boris Johnson rolls the Brexit dice again
text:
LONDON — Boris Johnson is gambling on MPs making their own Brexit cliff edge.

The U.K. prime minister offered Labour's Jeremy Corbyn more time to scrutinize his Brexit deal — but only on the condition he backs a general election before Christmas.

In a letter to the Labour Party leader on Thursday evening, ahead of an expected offer from the EU of a three-month Brexit extension, Johnson made Corbyn a proposal he might struggle to refuse.

“We cannot risk further paralysis,” the prime minister wrote. “In these circumstances, the Commons will vote next week on whether to hold an election, to be held on December 12.”

The plan allows MPs the extra days of Brexit scrutiny they have demanded from the government (with November 6 set as the proposed date parliament would break to start the campaign) but comes at the potential cost of a public poll, on which lawmakers will get to vote on Monday.

Brussels could also wait until next week to get a clearer sense of the U.K.’s plans.

It gives MPs the option of creating their own Brexit cliff edge, after they removed the no-deal deadline of October 31 Johnson was previously hoping would force them to back his deal in order to avoid crashing out of the EU. Last Saturday, parliament blocked the government from holding a vote on the deal he clinched with Brussels, making him legally obliged to request the extension.

No. 10 believes MPs will continue to delay unless the threat of a deadline looms. “Unless there is a line in the sand, this parliament continues to vote to kick the can,” a senior government figure explained on Thursday night, speaking on condition of anonymity.

But MPs could — of course — reject the deadline altogether, with a two-thirds majority needed for it to pass. “If they refuse to vote for the election offer, that is up to them," the senior figure said. "They are going to have to justify to their electorate at some point that they didn’t want to do Brexit.”

A Downing Street spokesman said the government would go into effective hibernation if MPs reject the offer, only acting where necessary to keep the country on its feet.

“It will be a broken parliament,” the spokesperson said. “The government will pull the bill … and the offer of a general election is all that will come out of government from now until that general election happens.”

As an added bonus, Downing Street sees the offer as a triple-win with the public.

MPs can vote the bill through in the extra time, allowing Johnson to head into an election as a champion; they can vote it down in the extra time, allowing Johnson to head into a “people vs parliament” election on his Brexit deal; or they can vote against the snap election, adding fuel to the campaign narrative if the public poll ever comes.

Another unknown is what kind of Brexit delay Brussels will offer, or when they will decide. EU diplomats are set to meet to discuss the extension on Friday, which they are hoping can be agreed without calling another leaders’ summit next week. Council President Donald Tusk has urged EU27 leaders to approve an extension until January 31, as requested by Johnson's letter, a move designed to allow events to continue to shift in Westminster without ensnaring the EU in Britain’s internal politics.

To that end, the EU27 could just propose a three-month extension on Friday. However, after their last meeting diplomats said France was pushing for a shorter extension, in the hope of pushing the U.K. toward the exit after more than three years of dilly-dallying.

Brussels could also wait until next week — theoretically they could go quite close to the current October 31 deadline — to get a clearer sense of the U.K.’s plans. Such a delay could make the opposition less likely to back an election because they first want a guarantee that an extension has been granted.

Opposition opposed

Opposition parties appeared unimpressed with Johnson’s offer of more time with strings attached.

Corbyn previously said Labour would back an election once a Brexit extension is secured, to avoid the risk of falling out of the EU with no deal in the middle of the campaign. But on Thursday night he left himself a lot more wiggle-room.

“Tomorrow the European Union will decide whether there’s going to be an extension granted or not," he said in a TV clip after meetings with shadow Cabinet members. "That extension will obviously encompass whether there’s a no deal or not. Let’s find that out tomorrow.”

The news that Johnson had publicly admitted Britain will no longer leave the EU on October 31 “do or die” was entirely subsumed by the debate about the election.

Asked whether voters might be confused about Labour's stance, he insisted: “There’s no confusion at all.”

However, the Labour leader might be reluctant to face the country while his party is tanking in the polls, and many of his pro-EU MPs agree.

Walthamstow MP Stella Creasy told POLITICO the public should "see straight through" the offer from Johnson. "I am not going to vote to inflict the potential of no deal on my constituents until I know that that is absolutely off the table, as much as I want to get rid of this government," she said.

Wolverhampton MP Pat McFadden added: "The way to deal with this is to decide on Brexit first and then consider an election after that."

Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson made similar noises. “The Liberal Democrats will not support any election until it is clear that we can avoid crashing out with no deal, and that needs an extension from the EU,” she said.

Other smaller parties refused even to speak in code. Green Party MP Caroline Lucas said a general election “will not resolve Brexit, and it must not happen until no-deal is properly secured and until people have had a final say.”

Plaid Cymru leader Adam Price also rejected the offer. “Our priority remains delivering a final say referendum, rather than an election, as the clearest way to end the Brexit chaos,” he said.

Bad news (and good news) buried

The news that Johnson had publicly admitted Britain will no longer leave the EU on October 31 “do or die” was entirely subsumed by the debate about the election — another win for No. 10. "The vote on Tuesday was parliament's last chance to get Brexit done before October 31 and it voted, again, for delay,” Johnson wrote to Corbyn.

Also subsumed was the vote on the queen’s speech — the government’s legislative agenda — which it managed to win after weeks of expectation that it would be voted down.

The really bad news for MPs, as well as campaigners, is that they could be trudging the streets and knocking on doors during the cold December months. One journalist pointed out that sunset in Glasgow comes before 4 p.m. in the depths of December.

And MPs will not have been cheered by a new survey showing a majority of voters on both sides of the Brexit debate believe violence against them is a “price worth paying” for their preferred outcome.
